Dialogue: He drinks, mum.

Dialogue: Let's try.

Dialogue: Gunther! It's hopeless - we can't help them.

Dialogue: Hello the farm!

Dialogue: You are too young for war. And you're too young for women!

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I don't feel so young. Not anymore.

Speaker: gunther
Dialogue: Go to sleep - we have a big night of riding ahead. Goodnight, Michael.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Night night, Gunther.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: Hei! In die windmhle!

Speaker: gunther
Dialogue: Go, go, go...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: gunther
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: gunther
Dialogue: A promise.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Grandpre.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: The wind plays tricks with the noise - it's moving away from us.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: I can hear it, Grandpre, and there is no wind. You shouldn't lie to me.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Here. There is no wind here. But over there - a wind so strong it will lift you off the ground...

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: You lie about everything. You say you aren't worried but it's clear you are. I know the war is approaching but you say, "Oh, it's just a trick of the wind."

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Did I say that?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: You started lying when Mama and Papa went away.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: The truth is - He feeds her a spoonful of the medicine.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: If you tell me the truth about the war, I will tell you the truth about the big horses I've been keeping in the windmill.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Now - who is the one telling lies! EXT. COURTYARD. SAME.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: In the windmill?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Yes. They were standing in the windmill waiting for Don Quixote. This is Franois .

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: I named them after two boys who broke my heart last Summer.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: They must belong to someone. Horses like this don't just appear from a fairy-tale.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Yes - I know, Grandpre. They are not unicorns - so I will be fair and wait -- one day.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Emilie... Emilie...

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: And if no one comes to get them by night-time, then they belong to me.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Emilie. Look at me. You cannot ride.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Mother used to tell me how my bones would give way with the slightest bump or fall.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Yes. That's right. So it is settled? She kisses his cheek --

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: It will only be settled when I decide which one to ride first.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: But it's - Over my dead body!

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: At least I won't have long to wait.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Unfortunately he was in love with a girl called Marie, who had your teeth. She fell for a boy called Claude - who broke my heart. And who I intend to marry one day.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: He doesn't think we can do it. But we will show him, won't we?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: You'll kill yourself.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Only if you get in my way to make me fall.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Oh please, come off the ladd--

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Halt! Und aussteigen!

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: My name is Bonnard - this is my land. Why are you here?

Speaker: soldiers
Dialogue: Food for the soldiers at the front. Everyone must give their share.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: They are taking everything. Where are the horses?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: What horses?

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Leave it if you don't know what it's for.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: A pot is a pot. We'll find some use for it. Sir, where's the livestock? Brandt sits quietly, casually using his finger to scoop jam from an open jar.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: I make jam. We have no animals.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: But there's fresh hay in your barn.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: We use it to replace the mattress stuffings.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: Her grandfather?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: Where are her parents?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: They're dead. They died.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: The wind. It plays tricks in the attic.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: There is no wind.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: An old house creaks.  Go - close the shutters.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: She's sickly, no? GRANDFATHER If you or any of your friends harm her, as old as I am, I will kill you.

Speaker: german soldier
Dialogue: You know, I was going to give you back your pot. But now I'm going to keep it. For soup.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: We will be back in the new season.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: And you've never done a brave thing in your life?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Maybe there are different ways to be brave. Did you know the French have the best carrier pigeons? And this could be the difference in the war - our messages getting through.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: I don't want to hear about the birds.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: They are released at the front and told to go home - this is all they know. But to get there they must fly over a war. Can you imagine such a thing? Here you are flying over so much pain and terror - and you know you can never look down. You have to look forward or you'll never get home. I ask you - what could be braver than that?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: A present.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: I hope you have not bought me a disgusting dress that I then have to wear like last year.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: It was disgusting?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Yes. I looked like an ugly nun.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Anything you say, my sweet one. Anything-you-say! You are, of course, the boss. It's just an old thing I found - don't worry yourself - leave it, I'll put it back. He leaves the room. Now Emilie is alone and she can't help it when she brings her eyes back to the object covered by the rug. She looks back over her shoulder to make sure she's not being watched and then lifts one corner of the rug. Her face explodes with a gorgeous smile. She pulls off the rug that is covering the big thing and...it is a gorgeous old saddle. She runs her hand along the saddle -- can hardly believe it.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: It was your mother's. I hid it, so as not to encourage you. Emilie, I want you to ride very slowly, very carefully. And promise me you won't go far --

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Of course. Okay, I promise.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: To the top of the hill and straight back again.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: I promise.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Slowly...slowly...

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: No! Let go of me! No!

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: She is my granddaughter! Emilie, stop! Don't hurt her, please! Don't hurt her.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: You don't need them! There are so many others!

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Please, take the bigger one and leave the smaller one. You are breaking my granddaughter's heart.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: The war has taken everything from everyone.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: What will happen to them?

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: They will pull artillery until they DIE - EMILIE  Franois!

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: - or until the war is over.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: It will never be over!

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: You have your answer then.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: Heiglemann - these are yours.

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: They look strong - should last a month or two. FRIEDRICH is an unprepossessing, chubby man. He marvels at Topthorn.

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: You are beautiful.

Speaker: artillery officer
Dialogue: Pull together!

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: Stop! Stop!

Speaker: artillery officer
Dialogue: Heiglemann, bring up another horse!

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: That one!

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: He's a good horse, sir. But if you move him up to the heavy gun, he will be no use at all. Prince is already losing condition. His leg, sir.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: You have given them names?

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: You should never give a name to anything you are certain to lose. FRIEDRICH His leg is not good enough, sir.

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: Private, you will do as you are told.  Hook him up.

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: As you see, sir, this one is stronger. Brandt takes up Friedrich, and Joey's, offer -

Speaker: brandt
Dialogue: Hook him up.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Halt! Halt! Take the horses away!

Speaker: artillery officer
Dialogue: Shell!

Speaker: sergeant martin
Dialogue: Valuables in the bucket, lads. If you live, you'll get them back. If you live, you'll get them back. Good lads.

Speaker: andrew
Dialogue: Maybe it's a drill, Albie. Maybe it's a drill like last time.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Love letter?

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: That's my business.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I hear you and your mate were doing bird imitations again. You gonna write a letter to your horse?

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Stay here.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I remember you somersaulting through the air.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Who was that girl you were with?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: There was a girl?

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: There was. Don't you remember?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: It was just some girl, I suppose. I don't recall which one. I do remember you falling on your bum in a ditch.

Speaker: andrew
Dialogue: You did that? You fell on your bum?

Speaker: sergeant martin
Dialogue: Be ready! Be ready! Let's go, men, get ready to go! Get ready to move out! Stay in position!

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Hold your nerve, boys. Remember, it's not far to go. There's a way through.  Run fast, keep your wits about you, keep your eyes open and God and the King will keep an eye on you. Company will fix bayonets! Fix bayonets!

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: You know what it reminds me of out there?

Speaker: andrew
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: That bloody impossible lower field the day me and Joey plowed it. Best day of my life that was and you were there.

Speaker: andrew
Dialogue: And this here is the worst day of my life, about to begin, and you're here cheering me on. Us two, always. And him.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Come on, boys, come on. To the ladder!

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Stick close to the gentry, that's our ticket, yeah? We have the pluck but they have the luck. They both smile. And then the fear takes over again. Andrew particularly feels as though he is on the very edge now. David urges them forward.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: You, too, Narracott.  And you, too.

Speaker: sergeant martin
Dialogue: Listen to your sergeant!

Speaker: soldiers
Dialogue: Yes, sir!

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Do you understand me? Do you understand what I'm telling you, son? You take this rifle and you shoot them dead. Understand?

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: It's good. Andrew, it's good. Andrew! Nobody's retreating today. Andrew! Andrew! Nobody. Is retreating. Today.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I'm shot! No!

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: You'll be all right here. You'll be safe. Someone'll come for ya.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Albert. Albert, listen...

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: It's all right. It's all right. We're Devon boys, yeah? David looks at Albert as though seeing him for the first time.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: random soldier
Dialogue: Get down! Albert continues forward to dive into another shell hole, nearer to the German line. He scrambles from shell hole to shell hole. Now he's very close to the machine gun position.

Speaker: andrew
Dialogue: NO!

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: We made it. We made it.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Gas! Gas! Gas!

Speaker: andrew
Dialogue: Albie...

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Hey, there's no stopping here. Keep them moving.

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: Sir, there's something wrong. This one needs to rest.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: There's no rest for them. Move them along. Move them along!

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: Please, please, please. Stay on your feet. No, please. No no no...

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: They're coming! Leave it, private!

Speaker: friedrich
Dialogue: Go to hell!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: What the hell is it?

Speaker: geordie soldier
Dialogue: It looks like a cow.

Speaker: soldier 2
Dialogue: That definitely isn't a cow.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Well, what is it?

Speaker: second german
Dialogue: It can't be a horse. Nothing alive could be out there.

Speaker: third german
Dialogue: It isn't a horse. It isn't a horse.

Speaker: second german
Dialogue: Yes - it's a horse. The second German looks through the periscope, stunned.

Speaker: third german
Dialogue: It's a horse.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Yeah, it's a horse.

Speaker: british captain
Dialogue: Well, bugger me. It's a horse.

Speaker: geordie soldier
Dialogue: Lads, we should call him.

Speaker: british soldier
Dialogue: How do you call a horse?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: He's caught on the wire.

Speaker: geordie soldier
Dialogue: Oh sod it...

Speaker: british captain
Dialogue: What do you think you're doing? Get back, do you hear me? Corporal, that's an order! Get back!

Speaker: british soldier
Dialogue: Listen to him, sir. We can't leave him.

Speaker: second german
Dialogue: It's a trap.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: No, I don't think so. I think he's trying to help.

Speaker: third german
Dialogue: Scare him back into his hole.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: It's a white flag, ent it? You see the white flag!? I'm just after tending to this here horse, is all!

Speaker: british captain
Dialogue: Get back, you stupid git!

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I thought perhaps you might need these. He holds out the wire cutters. The Geordie, still frightened, stares stupidly at them.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah I... Ummm, thanks. Cheers. Cheers...

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: That...That's a very long strand. When you cut it, it's going to release this -

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: You speak good English.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I speak English well.  May I?

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Pity you didn't bring a second pair. Then I could cut the wire here -

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: WE NEED MORE WIRE CUTTERS!

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Say no more, I'm right behind you.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Delightful. We read, we knit sweaters, and we train our rats to perform circus tricks.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Well, if ever you need any more rats, we can always send ours over. `Cause we've more than we need, strictly speaking. Besides, they scare off all the pretty girls.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Our girls aren't afraid of rats. GEORDIE Big strapping German girls, eh? Kind what gives robust massages?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Every Thursday! And they bring rum cake on your birthday.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Look at that horse! Look at the muscles he's got, them long legs. They're made for running, horses. Runnin' away from danger.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Running away is all they have.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Yet we taught `em opposite. Running into the fray.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: War horse.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Yeah. War horse. And there he is. What a strange beast you've become.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: And now? GEORDIE I take him back with me, yeah?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Since I supplied the cutters, the horse is mine. This is fair, no?

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: In a pig's eye. He's English, plain to see.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Oh, you mean because he's so filthy?

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Because he's so smart. And you're none too clean yourself.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: We could box. And the winner gets the horse.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: No, thanks, pet. Must be careful not to start a war.  Do you have a coin of any sort?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Coin toss?

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Yeah. He takes a coin from his pocket, hands it to the Geordie, who looks at it.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: My name is not Fritz - it is Peter.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Peter - I'm Colin.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You call it, Colin.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Heads. Peter spins it in the air and lets it fall into the mud. They look down. Peter shakes his head, resigned.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: That's the face of my Kaiser and he does not look pleased with me. The horse is yours.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Gone quiet, hasn't it?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Yes.  But wait half an hour and we'll be shooting again.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: I'm a terrible shot, Pete, don't believe I'll ever hit the target.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Our strange beast.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: And you take care of your own strange self.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Colin! A pair of German cutters - in memory of your handsome friend from Dusseldorf.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Remarkable! A remarkable horse!

Speaker: sergeant martin
Dialogue: We're full up. Move on.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: The gas got him - we had to wait till morning.

Speaker: medical officer
Dialogue: This can't be all of us.

Speaker: sergeant martin
Dialogue: This is all.  All walking wounded, away to the dressing station! Away to the dressing station!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: What's this doing here?

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: We need a vet, sir.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: There are no vets. We've scarcely any horses left.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: He's cut all over, but this leg here's got the worst of it.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: It's probably tetanus. It's no good.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Please, sir -

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: I've all these men to take care of, corporal, you can see that, can't you?

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Please, sir, this horse can pull through anything.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: an orderly
Dialogue: It's a horse they found, wandering about in No Man's Land.  Down you go.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: What kind of an horse?

Speaker: an orderly
Dialogue: Bloody miraculous kind of an horse, be my guess. Nothing makes it out of No Man's Land.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Miraculous horse...

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: He was alive, y'see, sir, where nothing survives, so to me and me mates, to the men, sir, he's - Well, we have high hopes for him - DOCTOR You should shoot him now.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Oh, but I can't.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: It'd be a mercy, lad, that leg's not going to mend.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: Ladies, if you please.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Go on. Do it again. One more whistle.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Joey?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Do you know this man?

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Narracott, Private Albert Narracott, sir.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: This is a random horse, Narracott, and too badly injured.  Is this man in your care?

Speaker: an orderly
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: He's not random at all, sir! He's my horse, I raised him, in Devon. Sir, look at his legs! He's got four white socks, he's brown all over -  - and he has a white mark here - like so...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Take him back.

Speaker: an orderly
Dialogue: Come on, son.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Wait! You can't see `cause of the mud.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: All right, break it up. Clear off, the lot of ya.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: You see, sir? He's not random at all.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: major tompkins
Dialogue: Officers' horses only. All other horses are to be auctioned immediately.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: That is a complete and bloody outrage. It's the lad's horse, sir, from Devon. He raised him up from a pup, he did. Trained him right up to the day when the army came to town.

Speaker: major tompkins
Dialogue: These aren't my orders, sergeant.  You'll have to take him to market. That's all.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: We've all clubbed together. It's everything we have. There's twenty-nine pounds there. Buy him back.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Does the Major know?

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: The Major put in ten.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: Come on, Narracott! Get a move on. We don't want to miss the show.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Seven pounds! Seven pounds there! Seven pounds! Eight pounds here!

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: You're alright. Nobody's gonna bid more than fifteen for a thoroughbred. They want work horses.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Next one. We start at four pounds. Four pounds.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: It's the butcher from Cambrai. He's been bidding for the best all morning.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Eleven. Eleven pounds. Eleven pounds.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: Let me handle this, private.  Fifteen, and let that be an end to it.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: Sixteen.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Sixteen pounds.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: Seventeen.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: Twenty of your English pounds. And let THAT be the end of it, my friend.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Twenty pounds.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: Twenty Five.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Twenty five pounds.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: Twenty Six.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Twenty six pounds.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: Twenty eight.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Twenty eight pounds.

Speaker: sergeant fry
Dialogue: Twenty nine.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: And thirty.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: Any advance at thirty pounds?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: And sir, if you bid against me, I will sell the coat on my back and bid to one hundred and ten. And if you bid against me again, I will sell my farm and bid to a thousand.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: One hundred pounds. Going, going, gone.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Sir, I'll give you all your money. Everything you paid when we get back to England. I'll give you twice -

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: You don't know anything about him.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Oh, but you're wrong, sir, I know everything!

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Yes, you found him! I heard you found a horse in the wire between the armies -

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: No, I found him, he raised him -

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: When I heard about the miracle horse, I traveled three days because I knew whose horse it was. My granddaughter's. She saved his life! He was everything to her.

Speaker: geordie
Dialogue: Where is your granddaughter?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: The war has taken everything from everyone. He is all that I have left of her.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Don't be worried, boy, when I go. I won't worry over you none. Hey, I found you, didn't I, and you found me.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Do you know what this is?

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: It's my father's. It's his regimental pennant. How did you come by this, sir?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: You may have this.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: Thank you ever so much for this, sir...

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: ... And this.

Speaker: albert
Dialogue: What was her name? GRANDFATHER Emilie.  Her name is Emilie.
